Hi Gordon,

Thanks for your reply!

I'm still a little confused. Are all th=
e outlinks of a URI logged in the crawl.log whether or not those outlinks h=
ave already been discovered?

I'm not familiar with WARCWriterProcessor, co=
uld you explain more on that?

Thanks!
=C2=A0

--- 11=E5=B9=B43=E6=9C=881=
=E6=97=A5=EF=BC=8C=E5=91=A8=E4=BA=8C, Gordon Mohr <gojomo@...> =E5=
=86=99=E9=81=93=EF=BC=9A


=E5=8F=91=E4=BB=B6=E4=BA=BA: Gordon Mohr <gojomo=
@...>
=E4=B8=BB=E9=A2=98: Re: [archive-crawler] Re-discover links
=
=E6=94=B6=E4=BB=B6=E4=BA=BA: "HONGYING YI" <y195322@...>
=E6=8A=84=
=E9=80=81: archive-crawler@yahoogroups.com
=E6=97=A5=E6=9C=9F: 2011=E5=B9=
=B43=E6=9C=881=E6=97=A5,=E5=91=A8=E4=BA=8C,=E4=B8=8A=E5=8D=887:40


All the=
 outlinks discovered from a URI are inside the CrawlURI during 
its process=
ing, until it is finished (and logged in the crawl.log).

If you use the WA=
RCWriterProcessor, they are part of the data written in 
the 'metadata' rec=
ord associated with the URI.

Alternatively, you could insert your own cust=
om processor to log this 
data somewhere else (using the WARCWriterProcesso=
r's writeMetadata 
method as a model).

In this way, you can get the link d=
ata you want, without revisiting the 
same URLs many times (indeed infinite=
ly via link-loops!).

- Gordon @ IA

On 2/28/11 3:16 PM, HONGYING YI wrote:=

> Hi Gordon,
> We want to know all the out-going links and in-coming links=
 for each
> page, and in the example, for aol.com, aolhealth.com is an out-=
going
> link for aol.com, and drugchecker.aolhealth.com is an in-coming lin=
k for
> aol.com. If the link from drugchecker.aolhealth.com to aol.com does=
 not
> show up, we will not get all the in-coming links for aol.com. Is the=
re
> any way to retrieve that link? Can any configuration setting in the
> =
crawl get round that?
> Thanks!
> Yang
>
>
>
> --- *11=E5=B9=B43=E6=9C=881=
=E6=97=A5=EF=BC=8C=E5=91=A8=E4=BA=8C, Gordon Mohr /<gojomo@...>/* =
=E5=86=99=E9=81=93=EF=BC=9A
>
>

>=
=C2=A0 =C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=E6=8A=84=E9=80=81: "y195322" <y195322@....c=
n>
>=C2=A0 =C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=E6=97=A5=E6=9C=9F: 2011=E5=B9=B43=E6=9C=881=
=E6=97=A5,=E5=91=A8=E4=BA=8C,=E4=B8=8A=E5=8D=886:33
>
>=C2=A0 =C2=A0=C2=A0=
=C2=A0On 2/28/11 10:20 AM, y195322 wrote:
>=C2=A0 =C2=A0 =C2=A0 > Hi!We are=
 doing web crawling using Heritrix, and found one issue
>=C2=A0 =C2=A0=C2=
=A0=C2=A0in that once a link has been 'discovered,' it won't be
>=C2=A0 =C2=
=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0'rediscovered.' This means that if we have something like:
>=
=C2=A0 =C2=A0 =C2=A0 > aol.com->aolhealth.com
>=C2=A0 =C2=A0 =C2=A0 > aolhe=
alth.com->drugchecker.aolhealth.com
>=C2=A0 =C2=A0 =C2=A0 >
>=C2=A0 =C2=A0 =
=C2=A0 > and if drugchecker.aolhealth.com links to aol.com, that link will
=
>=C2=A0 =C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0not show up in the file.
>=C2=A0 =C2=A0 =C2=A0 >
=
>=C2=A0 =C2=A0 =C2=A0 > Is there any way to fix this problem? Thanks!
>
>=
=C2=A0 =C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0Usually a single snapshot crawl only wants to retr=
ieve each URL
>=C2=A0 =C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0once, so
>=C2=A0 =C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0=
this is by-design, rather than a problem.
>
>=C2=A0 =C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0Why d=
o you want to fetch aol.com twice in a single crawl? (Or am I
>=C2=A0 =C2=
=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0misunderstanding?)
>
>=C2=A0 =C2=A0=C2=A0=C2=A0- Gordon @ IA=

>
>
